sources.title: College
sources.description: Buster Keaton goes to college and trys to master sports ... all or any of them.

sources.title: College Keaton And Horne 1927 High Quality 1080p V 6xxc 0bli Wc
sources.description: Brilliant in his studies and dismissive of athletics, Ronald finishes high school at the top of his class. But in college his uptight attitude doesn't win him any points with his sports-loving classmates, and pretty coed Mary ignores him in favor of brutish jock Jeff. Hoping to impress Mary, Ronald makes a buffoon of himself at every sport imaginable.

sources.title: College (1927) | Colorized Public Domain Silent Comedy Classic with Buster Keaton and Anne Cornwall
sources.description:
College (1927) is a silent comedy classic directed by James W. Horne and starring Buster Keaton at the height of his creative powers. This colorized and restored edition of the public domain film revives one of Keatonâ€™s most entertaining works, blending physical comedy, satire, and romance. By enhancing the film with modern digital techniques, Colorized Public Domain ensures that todayâ€™s audiences in the United States, Europe, and beyond can rediscover this timeless gem in vivid detail.

Plot Summary:
The story follows Ronald (Buster Keaton), a brilliant but socially awkward young man who graduates as valedictorian of his high school. Obsessed with academics, Ronald dismisses athletics and mocks sports as unimportant. However, his disdain costs him the admiration of Mary (Anne Cornwall), the girl he loves, who values a well-rounded partner. Determined to win her back, Ronald enrolls in college and attempts to transform himself into an athlete.

In a series of comedic sequences, Ronald struggles to master baseball, track, football, rowing, and even weightlifting, failing miserably at each. His attempts are clumsy but hilarious, showcasing Keatonâ€™s unmatched skill in physical comedy and deadpan delivery. As Mary grows closer to rival suitor Jeff Brown (Harold Goodwin), Ronald realizes that winning her affection requires more than bravado. The climax comes during a high-stakes athletic competition, where Ronald rises to the occasion and proves himself not just as a scholar but as someone with courage and determination.

Film Significance:
College stands as one of the great silent comedies of the 1920s and a showcase of Keatonâ€™s physical inventiveness. Released just before the transition to sound films, it reflects both the charm and challenges of the late silent era. Unlike some of Keatonâ€™s grand-scale features, College is set in the relatable environment of campus life, blending everyday romance with exaggerated physical gags. For modern audiences, the film provides a window into 1920s American college culture, where sports, youth ambition, and personal transformation were central themes. Its comedic influence continues to echo in later Hollywood films that combine athletics and romance.

Enhanced Public Domain Explanation:
This film is in the public domain, which means it is completely free of copyright restrictions and can be legally shared, viewed, studied, and preserved without limitation. Colorized Public Domain restores and enhances these historic works through careful digital cleaning, visual restoration, and colorization techniques. Our mission is to ensure that timeless classics like College remain available to a worldwide audience. By presenting them in color and modern quality, we make them more engaging and accessible to younger generations who might otherwise overlook black-and-white cinema. This process respects the original film while providing a new layer of appreciation for todayâ€™s viewers.

Why Watch This Colorized Edition:
The original 1927 release was a black-and-white silent feature typical of the era. While authentic to its time, silent black-and-white films are often overlooked by modern audiences. By colorizing and restoring College, we bridge the gap between preservation and accessibility, ensuring Buster Keatonâ€™s brilliance reaches new viewers while preserving his legacy for those who appreciate classic film history.

metadata.Plot: Ronald's high school valedictory address praises books and condemns sports. His girlfriend Mary condemns his attitude. He fears losing her to rival Jeff, decides to go to college and pay more attention to sports.
metadata.Actors: Buster Keaton, Anne Cornwall, Flora Bramley
